Hey {first_name, "there"},

I'm breaking my "no more than one email a working day" rule here, but this is an important one. If you don't use Apple devices, or they're not critical to your work, you can safely ignore this, and my apologies for troubling your in-box unecessarily. If you do, then please read on. Apple has done something very odd, and it might impact you.

This is now today and it’s very good advice. I’ve seen lots of tweets from developers and others that their apps - as well as bits of iOS 14 itself - are just not ready. https://t.co/tGsH0Js8ju

— Marc Blank-Settle (@MarcSettle) September 16, 2020

Attention Creatives: We will be updating our app portfolio to #iOS14 all this week. If you are in the middle of mission critical work, we suggest staying on iOS 13 until the weekend to minimize any possible complications. Thank you! pic.twitter.com/xez0x9Kngy

— FiLMiC Pro || Firstlight || DoubleTake (@FiLMiCPro) September 15, 2020

sections: Apple announced last night that iOS14 (and iPadOS 14) would be available today — probably early evening UK time. I don't usually say this, but I strongly recommend you
upgrade if your iPhone or iPad is central to your workflow. This is an unusual situation, and it's really important that you don't rush to upgrade.

Although the new operating systems have been through their normal beta process, Apple traditionally gives app developers a week's notice of the release, and gives them access to the golden master (GM) build of the operating system. That allows them to build their app using the final version of the development tools, test it against the final version, and submit it to the App Store approval process.
This time, Apple didn't give developers a week's notice.
That means that many, and possibly even a majority, of iOS14-compatibility updates will not be available for your apps. Many will work fine, despite that. Some will not.
You DO NOT want to hit a bug right in the middle of a critical interview, or a piece of filming, or anything vital to getting your reporting out there.
(Quite why Apple seems to intent on pissing off its developers at the moment is quite beyond me.)
I'd hold off to the weekend at least, if you can. And it's generally good advice to hang on for the iOS14.1 release, which will probably only be six to eight weeks out.
I know the new shiny is so very tempting — I've been running the iPadOS 14 Beta on my iPad Pro for over a month now — but if you rely on your kit to get your job done, play it safe.
